Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Fundamental Studies of Two-Phase Flows of Binary Fluids Driven by Temperature Gradients

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511470 - Grigoriev

The principal investigators propose to develop a theoretical model where condensation of vapor on a surface significantly increases heat transfer rates. If the model is successful, it can help understand the mechanism of enhanced heat transfer and lead to design of more energy-efficient energy handling devices. The model will be verified by the accompanied experimental efforts.

This team of a theoretician and an experimentalist propose to develop numerical models and experimentally validate them for application of binary fluids in enhancing phase change heat transfer in multi-phase flows. The work builds on recent research involving multi-phase flows but adds complex approaches with pseudo-dropwise and film condensation. The approaches are novel and different in fundamental ways from prior research on the topic. This project will investigate convection in volatile confined binary-fluid layers driven by a horizontal temperature gradient. The transport model is aimed to accurately predict heat transfer enhancement and determine the specific conditions (in terms of liquid composition, maximum level of noncondensables, and subcooling or temperature gradient) required to maximize this enhancement. Condensation of binary mixture vapor both in the presence and absence of non-condensables is considered. Due to the favorable surface tension gradient (as opposed to the unfavorable surface tension gradient as in Marangoni convection) caused by concentration gradient, dropwise condensation is preferred. The principal investigators suggested that the favorable surface tension gradient can mitigate dry spot formation during evaporation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Efficiently transporting heat from one location to another is a challenging problem, especially when this is done  passively, that is without using an external energy source. One clever approach relies on phase change, i.e., evaporation of a liquid at a higher temperature and condensation of vapor into liquid at a colder temperature. This project considered bottlenecks in heat transport associated with both condensation and the flow of vapor and liquid in confined geometries. Due to the inherent complexity of the mathematical description of these processes, previous work relied primarily on either numerical simulations or scaling relations derived using limited experimental data. Either approach has severe limitations for both improving our fundamental understanding of the relevant physics and for engineering design. To address these limitations, the intuition from numerical simulations was used to make appropriate simplifications in the mathematical description allowing important characteristics, such as the net heat flux, to be written in an explicit analytical form. This allows one to understand how these characteristics depend on various paramaters, such as the physical properties of the working fluid, the geometry of the problem, and the temperature difference driving the flow. 

In particular, this project has identified two parameters as having a key role in heat transport. The first one is the composition of the gas phase, or more specifically, the fraction of air it contains. Air generally suppress phase change and the flow of vapor through the gas phase and, as a result, has an adverse effect on the heat flux. In practice, air is almost impossible to remove competely from the system, so quantifying its effect on heat transport is essential. The second important parameter is the composition of the liquid phase for binary working fluids. This composition controls the strength of the solutocapillary effect responsible for the  "tears of wine" phenomenon, where evaporation causes a thin film of water-alcohol mixture to rise up the wall of a wine glass. The solutocapillary phenomenon plays a beneficial role in heat transport, enhancing both condensation and the flow of the liquid towards the hot regions, thereby promoting evaportaion. Both of these paramaters greatly affect several bottlenecks in heat transport. 

Despite the focus of this project on the fundamental understanding of heat transport in two-phase (liquid/vapor) systems, its results have very important practical implications. To give just one example, the increasing demands on computing power are ubiquitous in both civialian and military applications. These demands cannot be met without increasingly powerful processors that generate enough heat to simply destroy themselves unless this heat is dissipated. The heat has to be removed in an efficient manner, while design considerations often dictate that the heat be transported across significant distances. Hence, almost every modern laptop, desktops or server employs one or more heat pipes -- wire-like devices which contain a volatile fluid inside and rely on phase change to remove the heat generated by the processor(s). The fundamental advances produced by this project will help improve the efficiency of heat pipes as well as design a new generation of light, compact, and energy-efficient thermal management solutions for use in computers and other high-power electronic devices sich as radars, power inverters, electric morots, and battery packs.
